question.title: Why does the compareTo method throw an exception?
question.body:
// File: Employee.java

public class Employee implements Comparable {
    public Integer salary;
    public int compareTo(Object e) {
        Employee other = (Employee) e;
        return Integer.compare(salary, other.salary);
    }
}

// File: Manager.java
public class Manager extends Employee {
    public Integer salary;
}

// File: Main.java, Contains the main method
public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Manager m = new Manager();
        Employee e_ = new Employee();

        m.salary = 0;
        e_.salary = 1;

        System.out.println(e_.compareTo(m));
        // System.out.println(e.compareTo(m));
    }
}

Can anyone explain to me why I am getting this error? I have initialised m.salary = 0 and e_.salary = 1 after creating objects of the Manager and Employee classes, which should set the instance fields in each Manager and Employee object to 0 and 1, respectively.

answers.body:
There is no such thing as "variable overriding" in Java. The Manager class's salary member is hiding the member from the Employee class. For the variable m, you initialize the Manager.salary member, but the compareTo method refers to the Employee.salary member, which is null. In short, drop the Manager.salary member, and you should be fine:

public class Manager extends Employee {
}

As a side note, since Java 5, the Comparable interface has been made generic. You can save some casting boilerplate (and gain some compile-time safety) by defining your Employee as Comparable<Employee>:

public class Employee implements Comparable<Employee> {
    public Integer salary;
    @Override
    public int compareTo(Employee e) {
        return Integer.compare(salary, e.salary);
    }
}

The problem is that you're declaring two separate fields - one in Employee and one in Manager. They've got the same name, but they're still separate fields. So each instance of Manager has two fields. (I'd personally encourage you not to use public fields at all, but that's a slightly separate matter.)

Let's make a very slight change to your code, just renaming those two fields so that it's clear what you're referring to in each case:

public class Employee implements Comparable{
    public Integer employeeSalary;
    public int compareTo(Object e){
        Employee other = (Employee) e;
        return Integer.compare(employeeSalary, other.employeeSalary);
    }
}

public class Manager extends Employee{
    public Integer managerSalary;
}

Then your Main class is equivalent to:

public class Main{
    public static void main(String[] args){
        Manager m = new Manager();
        Employee e_ = new Employee();

        m.managerSalary = 0;
        e_.employeeSalary = 1;

        System.out.println(e_.compareTo(m));
        // System.out.println(e.compareTo(m));
    }
}

Note how you're specifying m.managerSalary - but m.employeeSalary is still null.

Now when you call e_.compareTo(m), it's effectively calling Integer.compare(e_.employeeSalary, m.employeeSalary) - so it's passing null as the second argument. That tries to unbox both Integer values to int (as the signature is Integer.compare(int, int)) which causes the exception.

Going back to your original code, if you just remove the salary field from Manager, letting it just inherit the existing salary field without creating a second field with the same name, the exception will go away. (Although the use of Integer rather than int suggests that null is a valid value - so you should handle that in compareTo anyway...)

You define

public Integer salary;

both for your Employee class which implements IComparable and has a compareTo method as well as the Manager class that extends Employee. Your compareTo method:

    public int compareTo(Object e){
        Employee other = (Employee) e;
        return Integer.compare(salary, other.salary);
    }

gets an Object e, converts it to Employee and compares salary with other.salary, where other is the converted object. When you do

        Manager m = new Manager();
        Employee e_ = new Employee();

        m.salary = 0;
        e_.salary = 1;

        System.out.println(e_.compareTo(m));

you:

  • instantiate m as a new Manager()
  • instantiate e_ as a new Employee()
  • sets the salary of m to 0 (that is the salary member of the Manager, not of the Employee, so the salary of Employee, the base class will be uninitialized, whereas the salary of Manager which shadows the salary of Employee is the one you initialized)
  • sets the salary of e_ to 1
  • passes m to e_.compareTo
  • internally, e_compareTo:
    • converts the object that you passed to Employee
    • so its salary is the base class's uninitialized salary instead of the subclass's initialized salary
    • hence you get the error

The solution is the following:

1. Don't shadow members in your subclass

Inside

// File: Manager.java
public class Manager extends Employee{
    public Integer salary;
}

the salary is completely useless, as you already have a salary in the base class and you can use it perfectly fine. So you will need to remove it:

// File: Manager.java
public class Manager extends Employee{
}

2. Avoid scattering value assignments

public Integer salary;

is bad design. You allow thusly to change the value of this field outside the boundaries of the class and you lose control and track on what may happen to it. Instead, make it protected and have a getter and setter:

protected Integer salary;

public Integer getSalary() {
    return salary;
}

public void setSalary(Integer salary) {
    this.salary = salary;
}

The reason is that getting and setting the value may become less simple in the future and you may have some validations you want to run each time you set the value, log when the value is being reached to, etc. etc., depending on your future needs.

3. Refactor the way you set and get your variable

// File: Main.java, Contains the main method
public class Main{
    public static void main(String[] args){
        Manager m = new Manager();
        Employee e_ = new Employee();

        m.setSalary(0);
        e_.setSalary(1);

        System.out.println(e_.compareTo(m));
        // System.out.println(e.compareTo(m));
    }
}

and

// File: Employee.java

public class Employee implements Comparable{
    public Integer salary;
    public int compareTo(Object e){
        Employee other = (Employee) e;
        return (
            (this.getSalary() == null) ||
            (other == null)
        ) ?
        0 : // unknown
        this.getSalary().compareTo( other.getSalary() );
    }
}

First read the very good Answer by Jon Skeet, the Answer by Mureinik, and the Answer by Lajos Arpad. Then we can flesh-out their fixes to make a fully working example.

As those Answers noted, you repeated your salary field across both superclass and subclass. Doing so is unnecessary and problematic. The subclass inherits from the superclass its public, protected, and possibly no-scope-modifier fields, as discussed here. So the subclass should be as follows.

Also, by default the subclass implicitly calls the superclass's no-argument constructor (super()). So we need a constructor in subclass that calls our superclass’ constructor with arguments.

public final class Manager extends Employee
{
    public Manager ( final String theName , final Integer theSalary )
    {
        super( theName , theSalary );
    }
}

I trust the Comparator.comparing methods more than I trust my own lousy code. So I did not implement the details of Comparable myself. Instead, I defined a static constant to hold a private static final Comparator instance. I define the comparator with a brief method reference, referring to our getter accessor method.

private static final Comparator < Employee > COMPARATOR = 
    Comparator
        .comparing( Employee :: salary )
        .thenComparing( Employee :: name );

You asked to compare salary. We should add a second criterion as well, to further sort when salary values are duplicated. I added a criterion of Employee :: name.

Modern Java offers sealed classes/interfaces. This feature restricts which other classes or interfaces may extend/implement them. So I marked Employee as sealed with permits Manager. And I marked Manager as final.

By the way, you may or may not want to use the JavaBeans convention of prefixing accessor methods with get…/set…. I prefer not to prefix unless required by some framework.

Resulting Employee class code:

public sealed class Employee
        implements Comparable < Employee >
        permits Manager
{
    // Statics
    private static final Comparator < Employee > COMPARATOR = 
        Comparator
            .comparing( Employee :: salary )
            .thenComparing( Employee :: name );

    // Fields.
    protected String name;
    protected Integer salary;  // Make `protected` rather than `private` to allow access by subclasses.

    // Constructors.
    public Employee ( final String theName , final Integer theSalary )
    {
        // Validate inputs.
        Objects.requireNonNull( theName );
        if ( theName.isBlank() ) throw new IllegalArgumentException( "Invalid name string: " + theName );
        Objects.requireNonNull( theSalary );
        if ( theSalary < 0 ) throw new IllegalArgumentException( "Invalid salary: " + theSalary );
        // Assign fields.
        this.name = theName;
        this.salary = theSalary;
    }

    // Accessors.
    public String name ( ) { return this.name; }
    public Integer salary ( ) { return this.salary; }

    // Implement `Comparable`.
    @Override
    public int compareTo ( final Employee other ) { return Employee.COMPARATOR.compare( this , other ); }

    // `Object` overrides.
    @Override
    public boolean equals ( final Object o )
    {
        if ( o == null || getClass() != o.getClass() ) return false;
        final Employee employee = ( Employee ) o;
        return  Objects.equals( salary , employee.salary ) && Objects.equals( name , employee.name ) ;
    }

    @Override
    public int hashCode ( ) { return Objects.hash( salary , name ); }

    @Override
    public String toString ( )
    {
        return "Employee{" +
                "name='" + name + '\'' +
                ", salary=" + salary +
                '}';
    }
}

Example usage:

public class App
{
    static void main ( )
    {
        SequencedSet < Employee > workers =
                new TreeSet <>(
                        List.of(
                                new Manager( "Alice" , 20 ) ,
                                new Employee( "Bob" , 10 ) ,
                                new Employee( "Carol" , 30 ) ,
                                new Employee( "Davis" , 10 ) ,
                                new Employee( "Erin" , 50 )
                        )
                );
        workers.forEach( IO :: println );
    }
}

When run:

Employee{name='Bob', salary=10}
Employee{name='Davis', salary=10}
Employee{name='Alice', salary=20}
Employee{name='Carol', salary=30}
Employee{name='Erin', salary=50}

For the opposite direction, descending rather than ascending, add a call to Comparator#reversed when initializing the constant Comparator.

That code above was written for Java 25+. If using earlier Java, you may need to change a few things. This might include: Swap out IO for System.out, and swap out SequencedSet for NavigableSet. And you might need to add public to static void main. And remove sealed/permits.

In real work I would likely use JSpecify nullability annotations. And I would likely use Jakarta Validation to validate state.

question_comments.body: If an empoyee always has a salary (also when it may be 0), you should definitely prefer a primitive int over an Integerreference. The latter introduces a needless risk of a NullPointerException. As you have seen. Also I recommend constructors with arguments so you are sure that you always set the fields when instantiating objects.
less memory, (slightly) faster, ... is sure depends on your use case, on data model, but if you don't need it to be an Object, then better use int, especially if doing calculations with it
@user85421 Sorry, I didn't know that compare takes primitive int as arguments. But, is there a reason to prefer int over Integer?
Also note that using raw types is strongly discouraged (like in class Employee implements Comparable{)

why are you using the static Integer.compare(int, int), that takes two primitive int, to compare Integer; instead of using Integer.compareTo((Integer) which compares the wrapper Integer? Actually, why are you using Integer instead of primitive int at all??

This question is similar to: What is a NullPointerException, and how do I fix it?. If you believe it’s different, please edit the question, make it clear how it’s different and/or how the answers on that question are not helpful for your problem.
Please edit your question to include the full complete error message you get, including the stack trace.

79763729.body: Comparable → JLS 4.8 Raw Types: "The use of raw types is allowed only as a concession to compatibility of legacy code. The use of raw types in code written after the introduction of generics into the Java programming language is strongly discouraged." (even back in Java 6)
@BasilBourque Indeed, both of you are right, thank you for the observation.
@user85421 Thanks for this comment. Indeed you are right, I have not worked with Java for quite a while and took that line from the question at face value. Thanks again for your observation.
I think your implements Comparable should be a parameterized type implements Comparable < Employee > but I’m not certain. And btw, very helpful Answer you posted, well-done.
static Integer.compare is used to compare primitive int, not recommended for wrapper Integer - actually not clear why use Integer at all

79763696.body: @user85421 The Integer.compareTo(Integer) method may be marginally better ... or no measurable difference. It will depend on how the JIT compiler's optimizer deals with it. The difference between the methods is where the unboxing will occur.
actually using the static Integer.compare(int, int) to compare Integer is probably not the best
Using Integer rather than int here could cause a null pointer exception in the Integer.compare unboxing if a value is null. Tricky for a beginner to understand what is happening.

79763948.body: A well-written good answer. Nicely done.
